textPlain: News outlets have been feeding us with annualized rates, which is making this 0.9 figure sound pale, but it's pretty big because it's for July only. Times 12, it means inflation over 10%. The 3.3% annualized figure in the article is because they've been averaging the past 12 months.Something in July made the prices jack up in a really serious way.

Link to the BLS PPI release:
https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/ppi.pdf

Just to be pedantic, but the 10% number is the one that is annualized (that is, if an entire year had that monthly rate, what would its inflation be?). It's also not times 12, inflation composes, so it totals to ~11.3%.The 3.3% figure is annual, normally called "last 12 months" to avoid confusion with a fixed year.
Isn't that when the tariffs really took effect?
Is one month really enough data to distinguish signal from noise?
